Hi

  I'am also quite sceptical about using EC and a pure
neural networks architecture to control a robot in
such a good way. 

  1) Optimizing control parameters by using a solid
physics simulation
    - Those simulations are slow, not accurate, prone
to numerical instabilities, not the good candidate for
stochastic optimizers
    - Going from simulation to reality is hard.
    - There is a boostraping problems : as instance
for 2 legs robots, a random set of parameters are
likely to make the robot falling and miserably
crawling on the floor.
    - Any works on EC and robotics provides guarantee
on the optimized controlers. Optimal control theory
guys can do that.
    - People that are doing real robots don't believe
in it at all

  2) Optimizing control parameters on the real
hardware
    - 100000 fitness evaluations ? Expensive robot ?
If the evaluations are local to an engine behavior and
a 1 sec time frame, no problem, you got plenty of
evaluations. If the fitness is the global robot
behavior on a time frame of 10 minutes, just forget
about it. Optimal control theory guys can optimize
their 2 or 3 parameters with a quadratic problem
solver in minutes.
    - Stochastic search on real robot to improve that
very same robot behavior imply random try : "Ok, let's
try moving close to that cliff..."

Alex,

--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> a �crit :

> I think that the entire array of behaviors shown by
> this robot are 
> beyond anything that EC on its own can evolve today.
>  However, EC 
> certainly could have been a part of optimizing a
> subset of the 
> behaviors or their associated parameters (which is
> basically what 
> they did at UT Austin).
> 
> I do believe that EC will be able to evolve
> capabilities like these 
> in the future entirely on its own.  However, so far
> we haven't seen 
> that happen.
> 
> ken
> 
>
